Text_Numeracy: It was only a couple years ago, so I think it was October/November of 2021. I had just gotten out of a FULL long shift at work, and had just done a full week of work as a personal trainer. I felt like I had this draw, or energy to get on some sort of exercise device or something to be active at my house. Instead of going to my usual cardio machine, I felt like getting on the rowing machine. When I got on, I had goosebumps all over me. The kind of goosebumps you get when someone speaks truth, or some kind of emotion hits you. I was instantly flooded with all these memories, and things I had been feeling about being miserable for the last couple years of my life. When I say miserable, I mean it was REALLY REALLY bad. Anyway. I ended up fighting through this workout on the rowing machine, and at the end it ending up being my best time EVER on the machine, for that distance. Text_Numeracy: I want to tell you a story of a few friends of mine where their medical knowledge and awareness saved their life and the life of their son. One time they just went out for a normal dinner, and they got a babysitter and went to the restaurant. The mom began to have a seizure at the restaurant, and the dad was not sure what to do. It was an odd situation, and he leveled with everything happening around him. He was able to have lots of quick answers for things people were telling him to do to help his spouse. The dad yelled to the people at the restaurant to call an ambulance because his wife was having a seizure. The restaurant called the ambulance really quickly.The wife was a little coherent, and she was able to tell the people in the restaurant that hey needed her medicine which can be a good treatment for seizures. The ambulance came quickly and saved the woman's life. She has more difficulty with seizures now, but the death rate is very low because it does not occur that often.

Text_Numeracy:
I have been through two controlled research studies, one focused on a pain medication and one focused on a diet medication. I had a study manager and a physician that I could contact at any time. 

The only thing that I had to do on my own was to fill out a form online once a week and come in for pre-scheduled appointments. 

I had painful headaches at the end of the day, I would take ibuprofen before bed and it would usually take care of it. 

When I started the study for the pain medication, I realized that I was not going to have ibuprofen for a month. I didn’t know if I was strong enough to do that. 

Once the week was over I didn’t have ibuprofen or any other analgesics (there is no way to tell a patient's reaction if they are on meds) 

I was sick for several hours and felt like I was going to die. I did this over a month and realized that I could quit taking the pills. 

Every once in a while I notice a headache coming on and I don’t want to have to deal with this again.
Text_Anxiety: consequences of receiving bad news

Then I eased her slowly to her side, because I was unsure if she was coming to, or if another seizure was coming on.  After I felt she was safe on her side, I sent one friend to find her mom, who we knew was nearby.  I then went and gathered everyone’s belongings so they could go.  I helped talk her mom through monitoring and caring for her until she was deemed safe to go home.  Other than that, I try to stay generally aware of what is going on in the medical field.

Text_Numeracy: When I was 23 years old, I had a severe allergic reaction shortly after taking an antibiotic prescribed by physician. I had hives and swelling reportedly 90% of my body and had shortness of breath and a tingling sensation in my body. My Mother was a nurse who worked in a ICU unit and she was trained to recognize that I was in a grave condition at home. She used some professional tools that she had at home and turned out my oxygen saturation was in the low 80's. She immediately called for an ambulance and pack a bag for me to take to the hospital. The condition of my body continued to deteriorate during the ambulance ride to the hospital. Once there, the emergency room doctors quickly diagnosed the condition as a true allergic reaction and were able to treat me with a dose of epinephrine and intravenous fluids as well as some steroids for inflammation. I had to remain in the hospital for 3 days to monitor me through recovery since allergic reactions can get worse instead of better.
Text_Anxiety: I worry that the doctor will tell me something I don't want to hear. I'm also worried that the issues I'm having can't be fixed.
Text_TrustPhys: I trust my doctor because he is highly educated & experienced, takes time to explain things, and listens to my concerns. He works with me to come up with the best treatment/medication.
Text_SubjectiveLit: As an AI model, I don't have personal beliefs or opinions, but I can offer information based on what I've been programmed with. Most people can understand basic health information because they have been trained in medical terminology and procedures. Most people feel that they have an adequate understanding of these things to protect and optimize their health.

Text_Numeracy: 99 percent of the time if not more I go to research all medical issues I ever have that whatsoever raise my awareness to check on always in favor of the health and medical field.
Text_Anxiety: I feel anxious that what they going to do to me. Will they find something wrong. Can I handle what is wrong if they find something. How much would it cost for the procedure if they do find something wrong. Here it is summertime and if I do have to have something done, would they be able to do the procedure right away or would it have to wait.

Text_SubjectiveLit: I feel that I have an understanding of all medical information presented to me as well as the capacity to process and make to make relevant decisions regarding my health because my husband is a nurse and we speak of my medical needs often whenever anything arises. Thank you very much for your time

Text_Numeracy: An experience in my life that demonstrated my knowledge of health or medical issues is when i had a popliteal cyst. I'm a footy player and during the game i felt a tear in my calf and felt a lump appear at the back of my leg over the next few days. I sought medical help but in between i did my own research and was able to understand what the problem was before seeing the doctor.
Text_Anxiety: I'm very concerned about the cost of medical care in the US. I don't have medical insurance.
Text_TrustPhys: my doc is the only doc i see and she is very kind and helpful
Text_SubjectiveLit: very high self efficacy and understand 100 percent everything a doctor tells me about past medical history, procedure, aftercare, diagnosis, medications, any follow up appointments and then sometimes i have questions for the doctor and so they're great with answering them. i can also sometimes help my husband understand if he gets a little lost

Text_Numeracy: As a personal trainer, I will often utilize the knowledge I acquired throughout my studies to help empower my client and personalize their experience fitness with workouts and meal that are specifically catered to their needs for their fitness goals.
Text_Anxiety: When I was young my mother would sometimes call a family friend who was a doctor for advice. She would bring me along. The doctor's house was big and elaborate and he had a lot of impressed gadgets like a microscope and landcruiser. So I guess I got a sense that doctors made a lot of money and got me thinking "what would I have to do to afford a big house and a landcruiser?"
Text_TrustPhys: Since moving to a new city I haven't made any appointments for medical care with any doctors or primary care physicians. Therefore I don't really have an opinion of them at this time.
Text_SubjectiveLit: The few questions you've asked so far have been fairly straight forward and simple to answer. I have filled out much longer and more complicated health questionnaires before than what you've provided thus far.

Text_Numeracy: I foud out that I had an increased cholesterol level.. I started eating better instead of the doctor prescribing me medication. I lowered my cholesterol naturally.
Text_Anxiety: No reply
Text_TrustPhys: He is a really trustworthy doctor. He always sees to my needs and makes sure that all my concerns are addressed. If he cannot help me, he always refers to someone who can.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I think I have the capacity to make basic health decisions just as easily as anyone else

Text_Numeracy: When I was pregnant at the age of 40 with high risk factors I had to make the decision to do genetic testing on my unborn child. I had knowledge of the medical issues that could arise
Text_Anxiety: When I go to the doctor's office, I always dread hearing bad news or something going wrong. I don't like getting needles or my blood drawn, even though it doesn't hurt like it used to.  I always seem to think of the worst.
Text_TrustPhys: I trust my PCP mostly for his knowledge, thoroughness and professionalism. He takes time during each visit to ask me questions and understand my culture and lifestyle. Thus he has the necessary tools and knowledge to provide the best care possible.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I feel I have a good overall capacity to understand health information in most all common ways, but some medical terminologies or responses I don't fully understand but can when going back to research it online at a later date ask my doctor privately over the phone or through my medical area online.

Text_Numeracy: I haven't had a lot of issues with my health, but several years back I went in for a routine check up and I apparently had too high of cholesterol. I was worried it was hereditary since my father has high cholesterol, but my doctor said mine wasn't bad enough to warrant meds yet and suggested I modify my diet. With the help of three different diet programs and a lot of reading up on the types of foods that are good and bad for cholesterol, I've been able to get my levels to normal range without meds!
Text_Anxiety: what makes me feel most anxious or worried when visiting the doctor's office is when I am concerned that some test will reveal problems I was unaware of.  For example, I have a concern that I may develop diabetes, so when a have a blood test for sugar, I am a little anxious until I find out the results.  normally, I am in good health, as I am active, eat healthy, and don't smoke or drink.  So I usually feel fine and comfortable, with the concern that there could be unknown problems like high cholesterol, high blood sugar, etc. that are revealed to me through blood tests.
Text_TrustPhys: My physician assures me that she cares about my health and well being. She listens to me. And she follows through with her statements keeping me informed and my well being on the front burner.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I feel very capable when it comes to health informatio. I can navigate websites and look for my own information.  I have also filled out paperwork at the hospital and doctors office.  Knowing the paperwork limited my hospital stay and getting processesundlebler.

Text_Numeracy: One significant experience that demonstrated my knowledge of health and medical issues was when I began to experience unusual fatigue and muscle weakness, prompting me to conduct thorough research on possible causes. I quickly identified that these symptoms could be linked to the medications I was taking and how they interacted with each other. Equipped with this information, I was able to discuss my concerns with the psychologist during my visit, helping to pinpoint potential adjustments to my treatment plan. This proactive approach reinforced the importance of understanding the complexities of medication management and its effects on my overall health.
Text_Anxiety: I wouldn't say I feel anxiety when meeting doctors. I’m very focused on maintaining my health and have a routine for my medication, so I approach these visits with a sense of purpose. However, if I did feel anxious, it might stem from the fear of not receiving the information I need about my medications or my health. I prefer to stay in control of my health-related decisions, and any uncertainty around that could potentially be bothersome.
Text_TrustPhys: I don’t have a primary care physician, and my experiences with doctors vary. I tend to distrust them because I often feel they don’t fully understand my commitment to living in the best possible health, especially considering my extensive use of prescription medications. I find that some doctors don't take the time to discuss all my concerns, and instead focus solely on their own agendas or standard protocols. This lack of personalized attention sometimes makes me hesitant to fully trust their advice or recommendations. My frequent visits to various specialists can also complicate building a consistent relationship with a single physician, which further fuels this distrust.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I feel quite confident in my capacity to obtain, process, and understand basic health information and services needed for making health decisions. My commitment to living in the best possible health drives me to actively seek out information on my prescriptions and any health-related topics that impact my physical activity. However, I realize that since I don't have a primary care physician, my ability to make comprehensive health decisions could be limited without professional guidance. I approach health decisions with a practical mindset, focusing on what aligns with my strong self-control and commitment to well-being.
